questions.text: Which of the following determines the sex of the fetus?
questions.solution:
The sex of the fetus is determined by Yp11, which is a region present on the short arm of the Y chromosome.

It contains the SRY gene, which produces the protein called the testis determining factor. This causes the gonads to develop into the testes. The target gene for SRY which favours testis differentiation is SOX9.

If SRY gene or Y chromosome are absent, the gonads develop as ovaries. The genes that favor this are:

  • WnT4
  • Rspo
  • DAX1

Related Pearl: Sexual Differentiation

questions.text: When does the sexual differentiation of the fetus occur?
questions.solution:
Sexual differentiation of the fetus occurs only after the 7th week of development. 

The chromosomal and genetic sex of an embryo is determined at fertilization by the kind of sperm that fertilizes the ovum (X or Y). However, male and female morphological characteristics begin developing after the 7th week. At the end of the 6th week of development, it is impossible to distinguish between the two sexes.

Related Pearl: Sexual Differentiation

questions.text: Where is the lower part of the vagina derived from?
questions.solution:
The lower part of the vagina is derived from the urogenital sinus. 

Option A: The ovary and the testis are derived from the genital ridge. 

Option C: The upper part of the vagina is derived from the paramesonephric duct or Mullerian duct. The uterus develops from the fusion of the right and left paramesonephric ducts in the midline. 

Option D: The labia minora and the ventral aspect of the penis are derived from the urogenital folds. 

Related Pearl: Homologous structures in male and female genitalia

Ovary Genital ridge Testis
Ova Primordial germ cells Spermatozoa
Labia majora Labioscrotal swelling Scrotum
Labia minora Urogenital folds Ventral aspect of the penis - penile urethra

questions.text: What is the vaginal epithelium derived from?
questions.solution:
The vaginal epithelium is derived from the epithelium of the urogenital sinus.

The epithelium of urogenital sinus is formed by the endoderm. 

Note: Urogenital sinus epithelium stains positive for FOXA1, and Mullerian duct epithelium stains positive for PAX2. In 2017, immunohistochemical testing done on embryos revealed vaginal epithelium showed positive immunostaining for both FOXA1 and PAX2.

questions.text: Which of the following structures in women is homologous to gubernaculum testis in men?
questions.solution:
The round ligament in women is homologous to gubernaculum testis in men.

Homologous structures are those that have the same embryological origin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of the paramesonephric duct?
questions.solution:
The Gartner's duct is not derived from the paramesonephric duct. It is a remnant of the mesonephric/ Wolffian duct. 

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesonephric (Wolffian) duct and Paramesonephric (Mullerian) duct

questions.text: What is the most common developmental abnormality of the uterus?
questions.solution:
The most common developmental abnormality of the uterus is septate uterus, followed by bicornuate uterus.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: Given below is the hysterosalpingogram of a woman who presented with infertility. Identify the uterine anomaly seen.
questions.solution:
In a hysterosalpingogram, the uterine anomaly cannot be determined as the external contour of the uterus cannot be seen. 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity. However, it doesn't show the external contour, so it cannot distinguish between uterine anomalies such as didelphys, bicornuate, septate or arcuate uteruses.

Transvaginal 3-D ultrasonography (3D TV-US) is very accurate for the diagnosis and differentiation of uterine anomalies. It is the first and only mandatory step in the assessment of the uterine cavity in patients with a suspected uterine anomaly.

Pelvic MRI without contrast provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours. It should be reserved for patients in whom 3D TV-US is not possible.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: A woman with unilateral renal agenesis presents to your clinic with a history of recurrent abortions. You suspect uterine didelphys. Which of the following would be the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is performed to confirm a diagnosis of uterus didelphys.

Uterine didelphis is a congenital condition that occurs when the incomplete fusion of Mullerian ducts that form the uterus during embryonic development leads to the development of two separate uterine cavities and two cervices, each with its own set of endometrial lining.

It is commonly associated with renal anomalies such as unilateral renal agenesis, severe renal hypoplasia, etc, and is often associated with recurrent pregnancy loss, preterm labour, malpresentation, and prematurity.

3D ultrasound, a non-invasive test, visualizes both the external (serosal) and internal (endometrial) uterine contours, effectively identifying anomalies. Hysterosalpingography (Option C) shows only the internal contour, making it unable to distinguish between conditions like didelphys, bicornuate, septate, or arcuate uterus.

The USG findings in didelphys uterus are two widely separated uterine horns and a deep fundal indentation.

Laparoscopy and hysteroscopy, being invasive diagnostic procedures, should be reserved for cases where simultaneous surgical treatment is planned following a comprehensive non-invasive assessment of a Mullerian anomaly. (Option A)

Intravenous pyelography is used to diagnose congenital renal anomalies. (Option B)

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome?
questions.solution:
Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.

The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving obstetric outcomes.

Metroplasty is the surgical resection of the intrauterine septum. This is done by approaching the uterus transabdominally via 3 methods:

  • Jones metroplasty
  • Strassmann metroplasty
  • Tompkins metroplasty

All of these methods are not preferred nowadays as they cause uterine scarring. 

 

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

questions.text: What is the sequence of pubertal changes in girls?
questions.solution:
The sequence of pubertal changes in girls is thelarche → pubarche → menarche.

Puberty marks the normal physiologic transition from childhood to sexual and reproductive maturity. The order of changes in puberty are: 

  1. Thelarche - It refers to breast budding, and is the first visible sign. It indicates the competency of the hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis. It appears between the age of 9-11 years, and is described using Tanner staging.
  2. Adrenarche - It refers to the generation of androgens (estrogen and testosterone) from the adrenal gland. 
  3. Pubarche - It refers to the development of pubic hair, and occurs usually 6 months after thelarche. It is also described using Tanner staging.
  4. Menarche - It refers to the first occurrence of menstruation. 

Growth spurt usually occurs between ages 10.5 to 13.5 years.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen?
questions.solution:
Pubarche or the development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both sexes. Around 50% of testosterone comes from the ovaries and the rest from the adrenal gland. 

Puberty in girls involves breast development (thelarche), an increase in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche), and the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche).

Estrogen has the following actions during puberty:

  • Breast development
  • Development of the reproductive tract
  • Starting of menstruation (option D)
  • Increased fat in the hips
  • Regulation of pubertal growth spurt
  • Vaginal cornification (option C)
  • Cervical mucus production (option B)
  • Epiphyseal closure
  • Maintenance of bone formation - acts against parathyroid hormone.

questions.text: You are examining an 18-year-old woman and it appears she has mature adult breasts. What is the Tanner stage of breast development in her?
questions.solution: The Tanner staging of the breast, in case of mature adult breast, is denoted as B5.

questions.text:
An adolescent girl is brought to OPD with a history of delayed menses. On examination, you note the following developmental changes. What is the Tanner staging?
  • The breast is elevated like a small mound
  • Pubic hair is long, slightly curved. Pigmented hair is present sparsely over the labia
questions.solution:
The breast elevated as a small mound and pigmented, slightly curved pubic hair is seen in Tanner stage 2.

Tanner staging Breast changes  Pubic hair changes 
Stage 1

B1 - Denotes the prepubertal breast. At this infantile stage, only the papilla is elevated.

 P1 - No pubic hair
Stage 2

B2 - Denotes thelarche. The breast buds are palpable, areola enlarges and the breast is elevated like a small mound.

 P2 - The appearance of pigmented hair sparsely over the labia, either long or slightly curved.
Stage 3

B3 - There is further enlargement of the breast and its areola without separation of its contours.

 P3 - Darker, coarser and curly hair
Stage 4

B4 - Preferential growth of the areola and nipple leads to formation of a secondary mound over the mound of the breast.

 P4 - Preadult stage cover short inverted triangular distribution.
Stage 5

B5 - Formation of the mature adult breast.

 P5 - Adult inverted triangular distributuion.

questions.text: Until which age is the growth rate of boys and girls similar?
questions.solution:
The growth rate of boys and girls is similar till the age of 10.5 years.

The growth spurt in girls overtakes that of boys for 1-2 years and reaches a plateau. In boys, the growth spurt starts later and continues for a longer duration. As a result, boys grow taller than girls in terms of final height.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the OBG clinic with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding. She attained menarche 4 months back. What pattern of bleeding would you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of puberty menorrhagia. Menstruation tends to be irregular and often prolonged. 

Since the hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis is maturing, initial cycles are anovulatory. Therefore, the pattern of bleeding is irregular. Also, as the endometrium is under the prolonged influence of estrogen, it gets thickened more than normal. Shedding of this thickened endometrium leads to prolonged bleeding.

questions.text: What is diagnostic criterion for considering puberty to be delayed in girls?

choices.text: Absence of menstruation by the age of 14 years
Absence of secondary sexual characters by the age of 14 years
Absence of menstruation by the age of 15 years
Absence of secondary sexual characters by the age of 12 years

questions.solution:
Puberty would be considered to be delayed in any girl who has not started menstruating by the age of 15 years.

Delayed puberty in girls can be declared on the basis of 2 grounds. These are:

  • No secondary sexual characters are present by 13 years of age.
  • Secondary sexual characters are present, but no menses have occurred by 15 years of age.

If any one of these is present, it's considered to be a case of delayed puberty.

Precocious puberty is considered if breast development or onset of puberty occurs in children less than 8 years of age.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of short stature and absence of menses. On examination, breasts are Tanner's stage 1. What is the most common cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of delayed puberty. The most common cause of this condition is constitutional. 

Puberty is considered to be delayed if:

  • Breast development doesn't occur by 13 years in girls.
  • Testicular enlargement doesn't occur by 14 years in boys.

 Causes of delayed puberty:

  • Constitutional or physiological delay (most common)
  • Chronic anovulation - PCOS
  • Anatomical:
    • Outlet obstruction
    • Gonadal agenesis
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome 
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism - E.g., Premature ovarian failure
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism - e.g., Kallman syndrome

Precocious puberty is considered if signs of puberty are seen in children less than 8 years of age. 

Causes of precocious puberty:

  • Idiopathic (most common)
  • Central
  • CNS tumors
  • Infections
  • Tumors producing
    • Estrogen
    • Testosterone
    • hCG
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

The protocol followed for evaluation of delayed puberty in girls is given below.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis?
  • Normal stature
  • Thelarche - absent 
  • FSH, LH - high
  • Karyotype - 46 XX
questions.solution:
The scenario of a 16-year-old girl with absent secondary sexual characters, normal stature, with XX karyotype and high FSH and LH is suggestive of pure gonadal dysgenesis.

46 XX and 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis without the phenotype of Turner's syndrome (short stature, webbed neck) is described as pure gonadal dysgenesis. It is characterized by the presence of primary amenorrhea with or without normal secondary sexual characteristics. 

Option A: Testicular feminizing syndrome occurs in karyotype XY. Secondary sexual characters are present and the uterus is absent.

Option C: Kallmann syndrome is a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. GnRH synthesis is reduced, therefore FSH and LH are low, and secondary sexual characters are absent.

Option D: Turner syndrome is associated with short stature and karyotype X0. Secondary sexual characters and the uterus is present, but the ovaries are streaked.

Related Pearl: Disorders of Sexual Development

Disorder

Complete androgen insensitivity

Mullerian agenesis

Turner syndrome

Complete XY dysgenesis (Swyer syndrome)

Cause

X-linked mutation of androgen receptor

Hypoplastic or absent Mullerian ductal system

Also called Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome

SRY gene mutation on the Y chromosome

Reproductive organs

Absent uterus and upper vagina, cryptorchid testis

Absent or rudimentary uterus and upper vagina, normal ovaries

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Normal uterus and vagina, streak gonads

Breast

Yes

Yes

Variable

No

Axillary/Pubic hair

Minimal to absent

Normal

Normal

Minimal to absent

Karyotype

46 XY

46 XX

45 XO or 

45 X mosaicism

46 XY

 

Note: 

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

  • 45 XO which is seen in 40-50% patients 
  • 45 X mosaicism (eg, 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/47,XXX, or 45,X mosaics with the X chromosome anomalies)

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions do secondary sexual characters appear to be normal?
  1. Resistant ovary syndrome
  2. Androgen insensitivity syndrome
  3. Mayer–Rokitansky–Küster–Hauser syndrome
  4. Imperforate hymen
  5. Transverse vaginal septum
questions.solution:
Secondary sexual characters appear normal in the following:

  • Imperforate hymen
  • Transverse vaginal septum
  • Absent vagina and functioning uterus 
  • Absent vagina and nonfunctioning uterus - Mayer–Rokitansky–Küster–Hauser syndrome [MRKH]
  • Resistant ovary syndrome

In androgen insensitivity syndrome, secondary sexual characteristics may or may not develop normally. The genotype is XY, however a female phenotype develops. These patients have well-developed breasts, but they have scanty body hair. This is because growth of sexual hair is only mediated via androgens. Thus, secondary sexual characters cannot be considered normal.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has come to your clinic with primary amenorrhea. On evaluation, height and secondary sexual characteristics are normal for her age. Ultrasound showed ovaries but no uterus was seen. Her karyotype is 46XX. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis. It is differentiated from androgen insensitivity syndrome as follows:

Presentation Mullerian agenesis  Androgen insensitivity /Testicular feminization syndrome 
Inheritance pattern Sporadic  X-linked recessive
Karyotype  46, XX 46, XY
Breast development  Present Present
Axillary and pubic hair Present Absent
Uterus Absent Absent
Gonad Ovary Testis (Intraabdominal)
Testosterone  Female levels Male levels
Associated anomaly Present Absent

Option C: Kallman syndrome is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. There is a lack of GnRH synthesis, and sexual development is delayed. Uterus is present.

Option D: Swyer syndrome is pure gonadal dysgenesis. The karyotype is XY and the uterus is underdeveloped.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. On examination, a bluish bulge is noted on parting the labia. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an imperforate hymen, which has led to cryptomenorrhoea. This is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.

The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx.

The most common causes of cryptomenorrhea are:

  • Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen.
  • Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen

Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Management:

Imperforate hymen - A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function.

Transverse vaginal septum - Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty is required.

Option A: Bartholin's cyst appears as a swelling on the inner side of the labia majora. Larger cysts can bulge across the introitus. Small cysts can remain asymptomatic.

Option D: Endometriomas are endometriotic lesions seen on the ovary. They present as adnexal masses. Endometriosis is a complication in cryptomenorrhea, due to retrograde menstruation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother with complaints of failure of onset of menses. On examination, her height is 150 cm, her breasts are underdeveloped, and sparse pubic hair is present. Ultrasound shows a small uterus and no gonads are visible. Which of the following statements is incorrect about her condition?

choices.text: Karyotype may have a Y chromosome
LH and FSH levels will be low
Pregnancy can occur with ovum donation
Estrogen and progesterone supplementation is the treatment

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of gonadal dysgenesis. Hence, the patient will have high LH and FSH levels as it is a condition of hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism.

Gonadal dysgenesis is the most frequent cause of premature ovarian failure. In this disorder, a normal complement of germ cells is present in the early fetal ovary. However, oocytes undergo accelerated atresia, and the ovary is replaced by a fibrous streak. This is called a streak gonad.

There are two types of gonadal dysgenesis:

1. Pure gonadal dysgenesis:

  • Karyotypes seen:
    • 46 XX is seen in pure gonadal dysgenesis due to FSH gene mutation.
    • 46 XY - Swyer syndrome
  • Associated with primary amenorrhoea
  • They are phenotypically female due to:
    • Absence of testosterone
    • Absence of Anti-Mullerian hormone secretion by testes
  • The underdeveloped gonad ultimately fails, which is indicated by elevated gonadotropin (LH, FSH) levels
  • The presence of a Y chromosome can result in a germ cell tumor in the dysgenetic gonad
  • Treatment:
    • Hormone replacement therapy - with estrogen and progesterone
    • Infertility - Pregnancy can occur with a donated ovum

2. Mixed gonadal dysgenesis:

  • Karyotypes seen:
    • 45 X0 - e.g. Turner's syndrome
    • 46 XX
    • 46 XY
    • Mosaicism
  • Dysgenetic gonad can develop into a germ cell tumor.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has come to your clinic. On examination, thelarche is absent. She has a normal stature, and her karyotype is 46XX. Which investigation would you prefer to perform first?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of primary amenorrhea. The first line of investigation in primary amenorrhea should be hormonal assay (LH, FSH, estrogen).

Following this investigation, USG pelvis and MRI pelvis can be performed to enable the anatomical assessment.

LH and FSH levels help to assess whether it is a hypogonadotropic or hypergonadotropic condition. The hormone replacement therapy is planned based on LH and FSH levels.

The various types of hypogonadism are as follows:

Type of Hypogonadism LH/FSH Estrogen Primary defect
Hypergonadotropic High Low Ovary
Hypogonadotropic Low Low Hypothalamus/Pituitary
Eugonadotropic Normal Normal Varied

Note: In a patient with primary amenorrhea with absent sexual characteristics, the first line of investigation is hormonal assay (LH and FSH levels).

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of 4 months of amenorrhea. Her FSH and LH were elevated above the normal value, thyroid function tests were normal. Which is the next step in management ?

choices.text: Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of premature ovarian failure. The next step in management would be to check serum estradiol levels to evaluate amenorrhea.

Categories of amenorrhea are based on gonadotrophin and estrogen levels as follows:

  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism - also known as premature ovarian failure. 
  • Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
  • Eugonadotropic hypogonadism 

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism/premature ovarian failure is present when:

  • Ovarian function is decreased/absent - Serum estrogen levels are low. Serum prolactin is high.
  • LH and FSH (gonadotropins) levels are high, as sex-steroid feedback is absent.

Differential diagnosis of premature ovarian failure:

  • Gonadal dysgenesis
  • Specific gene defects
    • Fragile X (FMR1 premutation)
    • Galactosemia
  • Iatrogenic
    • Ovarian surgery
    • Gonadal radiation
    • Systemic chemotherapy
  • Autoimmune disease
  • Toxins
  • Viruses
  • Miscellaneous

Note: Since FSH, LH, and TFT are already estimated, it suggests that all preliminary tests (including UPT) are done. Moreover, serum FSH and LH values are quite low during pregnancy. This is due to the inhibitory effects of elevated estrogen and progesterone.
